bibl.idno: The Papers of Henry Rose Carter [manuscript] ; HEALTHSCI MS-10.

bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, November 9, 1928

div1.p: Carter reports about a few final references she is working on as well as the possibility of filling in some maps for the manuscript of the History of Yellow Fever.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, November 9, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2222 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
November 9, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Miss Brown and I have put in another good week's work at the
Library of Congress and at my apartment, working at the latter place
at night and on Sunday.

Dr. Frost did not need me this week in Baltimore, after all,
but this mademakes no difference in the “ultimate outcome” as there is
still plenty to do here in getting advance work in shape for him.

Some few of the books we much wish to see are still unavailable, this
despite repeated search at the Library of the Surgeon General and the
Library of Congress and much writing re inter-library loans. Among
these missing books is a very important Spanish epidemiology by
Villalba (S. G.'s Library), which was used by Father, and quite re-
cently by Colonel Garrison, but which cannot now be found. I do hope
we can get a chance to see a copy before theFather's book goes to press. So
far, however, we can find no reference to any other copy in the States
save that at the S. G.'s Library.

I got a letter from Dr. Morley of the Carnegie Foundation the
other day, saying that he would be in Washington on December 4th. for
a week, when I hope we can do something, or plan something, re filling in our long-
waiting outline maps. I am stillalso hoping to hear from Dr. J. W. W.
Stephens concerning some references about which I wrote him, and also
from Dr. L. O. Howard's Librarian, also re a short list of references,
which she asked me to leave with her. Of course the bibliography has
reached the place where the “law of diminishing returns” is decidedly
in evidence--the remaining unverified references being those for which we have so
little data that we must supplement it by much hard work. I feel, how-
how-
-2-
ever that we have been unusually successful, considering the circum-
stances, and hope to be even more so before Dr. Frost completes his
final editing.
div1.closer:
With best wishes, I remain
Most truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
